bioghist.p: William Curtis Bok (1897-1962), the son of Edward William Bok, was a lawyer and judge in Philadelphia. He served in the Orphan's Court and the Court of Common Pleas before he was appointed to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania. Nellie Lee Holt Bok (1901-1984) was religious education director at Missouri's Stephens College for Women before her marriage to Curtis Bok. After their marriage in 1934, she became involved in politics, briefly broadcasting a radio program in support of Franklin Roosevelt's. She continued to write on the topic of religion, and was involved in local philanthropic activities.

scopecontent.p: The focus of this collection is the personal and professional papers of Curtis and Nellie Lee Bok. In addition, there is some documentation of their children (Derek, Enid, and Benjamin) and their Bok and Holt ancestors (including the Seymour, Easton, and Gianinni families). There are letters, travel journals, photographs, and printed materials relating to the illustrious careers of both Curtis and Nellie Lee. Notable correspondents include Franklin Roosevelt, Rachel Carson, and Princess Grace of Monaco. The collection includes manuscripts of writings by the couple, including an account of the coronation of George VI by Curtis Bok, and newspaper and magazine articles by Nellie Lee Bok. The collection also includes school records, diplomas, certificates, social diaries and calendars, and posters.
